title.value: Using rare genetic mutations to revisit structural brain asymmetry
title.justification: This is the title as presented at the top of the paper.
title.quote: Using rare genetic mutations to revisit structural brain asymmetry

extractions.description: The paper explores how rare genomic deletions and duplications impact structural brain asymmetry, particularly in regions associated with advanced cognitive functions like language and face recognition.

type.justification: The paper involves a systematic investigation of the effects of specific genetic mutations on brain asymmetry through real-world data collection and analysis.
type.quote: we quantitatively dissected the impact on brain asymmetry of eight CNVs

name.justification: The primary focus is on how genetic mutations affect brain structure and function.
name.quote: Our collective analyses demonstrate that rare CNVs impact brain asymmetry of specific brain regions involved in higher-order cognition brain systems.

name.justification: The paper analyzes the genetic basis of brain asymmetry.
name.quote: we leverage rare genomic deletions and duplications to study how genetic alterations reverberate in human brain and behavior.

name.justification: The study utilizes neuroimaging data to assess brain asymmetry.
name.quote: we quantitatively dissected the impact on brain asymmetry of eight CNVs

name.justification: The research connects brain structure changes to cognitive functions.
name.quote: we provide a link between the direction of CNV-induced changes in brain asymmetry and their impact on designated neural systems.

name.justification: The dataset is used for genomic analyses and contains imaging data.
name.quote: The present analyses were conducted under UK Biobank application number 40980.

referenced_paper_title.value: The UK Biobank resource with deep phenotyping and genomic data
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the primary reference for the UK Biobank dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Bycroft, C. et al. The UK Biobank resource with deep phenotyping and genomic data. Nature 562, 203–209 (2018).

name.justification: Used for obtaining imaging and phenotypic data.
name.quote: Data from the UCLA cohort provided by CEB (participants with 22q11.2 deletions or duplications and controls) was supported through grants from the NIH.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The detailed reference paper is not provided in this document.

name.justification: Used for preprocessing structural MRI data.
name.quote: Data for Voxel-Based Morphometry were preprocessed and analyzed running SPM12 (http://www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/software/spm12/)

referenced_paper_title.value: A fast diffeomorphic image registration algorithm
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the primary reference paper for SPM12.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Ashburner, J. A fast diffeomorphic image registration algorithm. Neuroimage 38, 95–113 (2007).

name.quote: Tissue-type segmentation into cerebrospinal fluid, gray matter and white matter...was achieved using FAST (FMRIB’s Automated Segmentation Tool).

referenced_paper_title.value: Segmentation of brain MR images through a hidden Markov random field model and the expectation-maximization algorithm
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the primary reference paper for FAST.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Zhang, Y., Brady, M. & Smith, S. Segmentation of brain MR images through a hidden Markov random field model and the expectation-maximization algorithm. IEEE Trans Med Imaging 20, 45–57 (2001).

name.justification: Used for multiple preprocessing steps including brain extraction.
name.quote: used the Brain Extraction Tool (BET) and FLIRT

referenced_paper_title.justification: The primary reference for the software library as a whole.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Smith, S.M. et al. FSL: FMRIB Software Library. NeuroImage 23, 208-19 (2004)

name.quote: FLIRT was used for linear registration

referenced_paper_title.value: FLIRT: FMRIB's Linear Image Registration Tool
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the reference for FLIRT.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Jenkinson, M., Bannister, P., Brady, M. & Smith, S. Improved optimization for the robust and accurate linear registration and motion correction of brain images. Neuroimage 17, 825-841 (2002).

name.justification: Used in processing steps for non-linear registration.
name.quote: FNIRT (FMRIB's Non-Linear Image Registration Tool) was used to register the images to standard space

referenced_paper_title.value: A global optimisation method for robust affine registration of brain images
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is a key reference for FNIRT.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Andersson, J.L.R., Jenkinson, M., & Smith, S. A global optimisation method for robust affine registration of brain images. Medical Image Analysis, 5(2), 143-56 (2002).
